content:
Bladder stones: Causes, signs, diagnosis and treatment

Bladder stones are a common disease of the urinary system. Stones are formed due to the deposition of minerals in urine, often found in people with bladder muscle weakness or urinary drainage obstruction. Small bladder stones may resolve without treatment, but sometimes bladder stones require medication or surgery. If left untreated, bladder stones can lead to infection and other complications.

What are bladder stones?
Bladder stones are hard mineral masses that form in the bladder. They develop when minerals in urine concentrate, crystallize and form stones. This often happens when you have difficulty expelling urine. (first)
Bladder stones occur more often in men than in women. Stones formed in the bladder are often large in size due to long-term accumulation of stone residue from urine in the bladder.
In addition, bladder stones are kidney stones that move down the ureter and fall into the bladder. Small bladder stones can pass out easily during urination. Stones larger than 8mm often get stuck in the bladder neck or urethra (the tube that carries urine out) causing painful urination, weak urine flow or acute urinary retention.

Signs of bladder stones
Sometimes bladder stones – even large ones – don't cause problems. But if a stone irritates the bladder wall or blocks the flow of urine, signs and symptoms may include: (2)
Lower abdominal pain; Pain when urinating; Frequent urination; Difficulty urinating or interrupted urine flow; There is blood in the urine; Urine is cloudy or unusually dark in color

Causes of bladder stones
Bladder stones can develop when your bladder cannot empty completely. This causes urine to become stagnant and concentrated. Concentrated urine can crystallize and form stones.
Some infections can lead to bladder stones. Sometimes an underlying condition that affects the bladder's ability to hold, or empty, urine can lead to the formation of bladder stones. Any foreign material present in the bladder tends to form stones in the bladder.
The most common conditions that cause bladder stones include:
Prostatic hypertrophy: (benign prostatic hyperplasia, or BPH) can cause bladder stones in men. An enlarged prostate can obstruct the flow of urine, preventing the bladder from emptying completely.; Nerve damage: Normally, nerves carry messages from the brain to the bladder muscles, controlling the bladder muscles to contract or relax. If these nerves are damaged by a stroke, spinal cord injury, or other health problems, your bladder may back up with urine. This is called a neurogenic bladder.
Other possible causes of bladder stones include:
Cystitis: sometimes urinary tract infection or pelvic radiation therapy, can lead to bladder stones.; Medical tools and equipment: Bladder catheters, small tubes inserted through the urethra to help urine exit the bladder, can cause bladder stones over time. When objects accidentally move into your bladder, such as birth control devices or catheters in the urinary tract. Mineral crystals, which later become gravel, tend to form on the surface of these devices.; Kidney stones: Stones that form in your kidneys are not the same as bladder stones. They develop in different ways. But small kidney stones can travel down the ureters into the bladder and, if not expelled, can develop into bladder stones.

Are bladder stones dangerous?
If not treated promptly and properly, the patient may face complications such as:
Cystitis: When the stones are small, the patient may not see any problems. Bladder stones that grow larger than 2cm often have symptoms of bladder irritation such as frequent urination, painful urination, interrupted urination or hematuria. If there is no early treatment, bladder inflammation can become chronic, leading to bladder atrophy, bladder fistula, and bladder cancer.; Nephritis: due to upstream bacterial infection from the bladder, can impair kidney function. This complication can greatly affect health and is very difficult to treat.; Lower abdominal pain: Patients often feel sharp pain in the lower abdomen due to bladder irritation and stones stuck in the bladder neck. Lower abdominal pain can spread to the perineum or the tip of the external genitals, causing discomfort for the patient.; Bladder fistula: Large bladder stones can cause bladder fistula, perineal or vaginal fistula in women. Urine leaks continuously through the fistula, causing infection in the vaginal or anal area. Patients will experience many inconveniences in daily activities.

Diagnosis of bladder stones
During a clinical examination, the doctor will pay attention to the patient's lower abdomen to check for bladder bridge signs, which is a condition in which there is a lot of urine in the bladder. In men > 50 years old, transrectal prostate examination is required. (3)
Tests commonly used when diagnosing bladder stones include:
Abdominal ultrasound: helps doctors identify bladder stones, record stone size and other abnormalities of the kidneys, bladder and prostate.; Urine analysis: helps evaluate bladder infections, identifies bacteria and crystallized minerals in urine.; X-ray: Kidney - Ureter - Bladder (KUB) X-ray will help the doctor determine whether stones are in the urinary system or not. However, some non-opaque stones will not be visible on a conventional X-ray.; Other tests: Cystoscopy: helps the doctor determine the number, size and location of stones in the bladder. In addition, cystoscopy also helps identify urethral strictures, enlarged prostate and lesions in the bladder. Measuring bladder pressure: helps evaluate bladder function and bladder muscle tone; Cystoscopy: helps doctors determine the number, size and location of stones in the bladder. In addition, cystoscopy also helps identify urethral strictures, enlarged prostate and lesions in the bladder; Measuring bladder pressure: helps evaluate bladder function and bladder muscle tone

Bladder stone treatment
Principles in treating bladder stones are: (4)
Removal of bladder stones; Treat the cause of bladder stones to avoid recurrence
Use medicine
Medications commonly used to treat bladder stones include:
Pain relievers and anti-inflammatories: Medicines help relieve pain and discomfort caused by stones; Urinary smooth muscle relaxants: Drugs that help widen the diameter of the bladder neck. From there, the stones can move out of the body easily.; Urine alkalinizing drugs: Drugs that help regulate urine pH, can be effective in dissolving uric acid stones.; Diuretics: Drugs that help increase urine flow; Antibiotics: treat urinary tract infections.
Surgery
Most symptomatic bladder stones require surgery. Surgical methods include:
Bladder lithotripsy: The patient is given spinal anesthesia or general anesthesia for a short period of time. Then the doctor performed an endoscopy of the urethra and bladder. The stones are visible on the screen and the stones are broken up with a laser or shock wave. Broken pieces of gravel are taken out with a basket. The surgery is safe, with very few complications. Patients may need to use antibiotics before surgery, which helps reduce the risk of infection.; Open surgery to remove stones: If the stone is too large (> 4cm), or the stone is hard and cannot be broken, the doctor may consider open surgery to remove the stone.

Measures to prevent bladder stones
To limit the risk of bladder stones, you should note:
Drink plenty of water: Every day you should drink 2 - 3 liters of water, which helps the body eliminate toxins and waste from the kidneys and bladder, thereby avoiding the formation of stones.; Add low-fat foods: Foods such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, low-fat or fat-free milk should be added to the menu every day. In addition, you should limit fried foods, do not use processed foods, canned foods.; In people with increased uric acid in the blood, foods rich in protein should be limited: Protein has the ability to accumulate uric acid in the blood, causing urate salt crystals to form and accumulate in the bladder. At that time, the patient will have a high risk of getting stones. Every day you should only add a maximum of 200g of meat, prioritize lean meat, chicken breast and limit seafood, shrimp, crab.; Supplement foods rich in fiber: Foods containing abundant fiber that you should supplement daily are vegetables, fruits, whole grains, beans... Men supplement about 30 - 38g/day and women is 21 – 25g/day.; Avoid using stimulants: You should limit the use of beer, alcohol, cigarettes and other stimulants. Because these chemicals accumulate in the body, they can easily form stones.; When there are signs of stones in the urinary system, patients should quickly see a doctor and get early treatment.

Bladder stones usually do not cause much impact on health. However, the disease can reduce quality of life due to urinary disorders. If not treated early, the patient can face serious complications, even life-threatening. Therefore, as soon as symptoms appear, patients should go to the doctor for timely diagnosis and treatment.
